intro: Rosa virginiana subsp. virginiana, commonly known as the Virgin's rose, is a species of flowering plant native to eastern North America. It is a shrub that typically grows to a height of 1 to 3 meters, featuring thorny stems and pinnately compound leaves. The plant produces showy pink to red flowers in late spring to early summer, which are borne on pedicels. Its botanical characteristics include simple, ovate leaves with serrated margins and fragrant, five-petaled blooms. This subspecies is often found in moist woodlands and along stream banks, where it thrives in partial shade to full sun.
